Name: Jogo de Guerra
Description: Jogo de Guerra (literally, "War Game") is a Risk-like game of war and conquest. Players throw dice to "liberate" countries and accomplish missions.

Name: Combiletra
Description: Combiletra (Combi-letter) is a word game from Sonata. Players shuffle hexagonal letter-tiles, draw them one by one and try to form words.

Name: Age of Battles: Sekigahara 1600
Description:
Sekigahara 1600 is part of the Age Of Battles table-top miniatures gaming system using 1/72 scale miniatures and the Shogun rule set. Sekigahara 1600 allows you to play the battle over four scenarios:

1. First Clashes
2. Red Devils Attack
3. Kobayakawa Choice
4. Shimadzu Clan Breakthrough

The boxed game set includes everything needed to play out Sekigahara 1600:

88 Samurai Infantry - tan/grey (two sets of ZV 8017)
51 Samurai Cavalry - tan/grey/red (three sets of ZV 8025)
20 Regiment Stands
12 Modular Plastic Trees w/stands
16 Laminated Regiment Cards
1 Pen
2 Rulers
1 Angle Pattern
1 Shogun Rule Book
1 Historical Description Booklet w/battle scenarios and unit tables

From the back of the box:
The military historical game "The Battle of Sakigahara" is based on the fight that took place in the plain near a Japanese village called Sakigahara. Here October 21, 1600 two samurai armies, more than 80,000 people each, met in the bloody battle. Tokugava Leyasu, an experienced general and politician, profited from the treason in the ranks of the enemy and defeated its troops thus stopping endless wars and establishing his shogunate in Japan.

This game is for 2-6 players. The enemy armies led by the players meet in the plain between mountains. Tactic maneuverings are very important in the game. Under a skillful leader a smaller army can defeat an outnumbering enemy. You can either recreate the historic battle or change the course of the fight. Anyway you should rely not only on the number of your army but also on your leadership and war skills.

Zvezda 8224

Name: Krebiz-4
Description:
This is the description on the cover:

Includes all the rules needed to for play:
- Capitalist Movement--A campaign game
- 7 scenarios for Capitalist Movement

Technical information including:
- More X-1 ships (Cruisers, Capsules & Combination Units)
- An advanced Starbase and Battlestation
- Krebiz Carrier and Control Ships
- Krebiz tactical concepts
- Krebiz units operated by other races
- Battleship variants

Also included: 42 pages of Companion SSDs displaying 42 Krebiz units

Expands

    Star Fleet Battles: Captain's Edition Basic Set

Name: Argonians-2
Description:
This is an expansion for the game Star Fleet Battles Captain's Edition. This is the description on the cover:

Includes all the rules needed to for play:
- The Argonians: a new star faring race
- Argonian fighter rules
- More Argonian starship descriptions

Historical background for the Argonians:
- Argonian history
- History for the Argonian First Republic (A Far Side race)
- 3 more historical scenarios

Technical information including:
- Ship descriptions for 70 Argonian units
- Argonian fighter rules
- Argonian ship names

Also included: 32 Companion SSDs

Expands:

    Star Fleet Battles: Captain's Edition Basic Set

Name: Mechad-1
Description:
This is an expansion for the game Star Fleet Battles Captain's Edition. This is from the description on the back cover and contents:

Includes all the rules needed to play:
- The Mechad: a new star faring race of machines
- Bolaar phaser capacitors
- Electromagnetic Field
- Power Distribution Nodes
- Trans-Warp Missiles
- The Distortion Cannon
- Subspace Whips

Historical background for the Mechad:
- Mechad history
- 3 historical scenarios

Technical information including:
- Ship descriptions for 25 Mechad units
- The Mechad tournament command cruiser

Also included: 24 Companion SSDs

Name: Far Side-1
Description:
This is an unofficial expansion for the game Star Fleet Battles Captain's Edition. This is from the description on the back cover and contents:

Includes all the rules needed to for play:
- Two new star-faring races
- Bolaar Phaser Capacitors
- Deflection/Transfer Device
- Option Mounts
- Krebiz Capitalist Alliance
- Variable Plasmas

Historical backgrounds of two new races:
- Bolaar Pirates
- Corporate Aggressors
- Tuforeous Dead Zone

Technical information including:
- A fleet data table listing all the new races ships
- all necessary annexes

Also included: 22 Companion SSDs

Expands:

    Star Fleet Battles: Captain's Edition Basic Set

Name: Official Rules of Card Games
Description:
This is a book of rules for common card games published by The United States Playing Card Company.  It also includes suggestions for how to choose which games to play, etiquette, and how to teach children to play card games. (This description refers to the 84th edition.)

This long running book is published by the same manufacturer of the popular Bicycle card brand of standard cards.

The new version of this book is now called: Bicycle Official Rules of Card Games

For the Hoyle Up-To-Date versions, see Hoyle's Games

Name: Monopoly: Toys 'R' Us Times Square
Description:
Now the world most popular board game lets you relive the thrill of the 60ft. ferris wheel, and miles of fun-filled aisles at the Toys "R" Us: Times Square Store.
-Game board features departments from the Toys "R" Us store such as Game World and Wheel World.
-6 collectible pewter movers: Nerf football, Tonka truck, Hotwheels car, Mr. Potato Head, Mr. Monopoly, and Geoffrey
-Plus a Ferris Wheel and painted wooden hotels and houses.
All packed in a collectible tin, found only at the NY Time Square Toys "R" Us.

Name: Journey to the Motherland
Description:
A cross between Trivial Pursuit, Charades and Pictionary, with an African-American twist.

Take a Journey and discover the history, past and present of great African-Americans who made substantial contributions to building the foundation of America.  Journey to the Motherland is an exciting and educational game that highlights black achievement and many areas of historical importance.

Contents: Game Board, Timer, 4 Pawns, 2 Dice, 1 Pencil, 1 Drawing Pad, and the "Guide to the Motherland" Game Booklet

Recommend Ages - "From Little Brother to Grandmother"

Name: Waterloo
Description:
Waterloo is a two player Grand-Tactical level introductory board wargame of the Battle of Waterloo.

First published in Japan by Sho-Kikaku as one of the Series: SS (Sho-Kikaku) in 1989.
Families: Players: Wargames with Rules Supporting Only Two Players

Name: 戦国ふぁいと (Sengoku Fate)
Description: This is an area movement Japanese wargame on the samurai era of Japan. Also has a second edition.

Name: Meeple Fling!
Description:
It's that time again!  Unity Games is here and all the meeples are ready to party!  They're gathering for a day of wining, dining, and dicing.  You're the host and you have to decide how many and which ones to invite.  Do you want an exclusive party where only select meeples are welcome?  Or do you want a wild riot of a party where everybody is welcome?  Each has its merits and both are subject to unwelcome party crashers.  The player who has the most valuable party at the end of the game wins.

The game was designed for and given to attendees of Unity Games X on January 21, 2006.

Name: Krebiz-2
Description:
This is the description on the cover:

Includes advanced Krebiz rules:
- Fighter Sabots
- The Krill series fighter
- Capsule Auxiliary Packs

Historical background for the Krebiz:
- Krebiz campaign notes
- Krebiz timeline and planetary system
- More historical scenarios

Technical information including:
- Ship descriptions for an additional 85 units
- The all-new Kraken old style dreadnought
- Three additional refits
- Defense satellites
- Bases

Also included: 30 pages of Companion SSDs displaying 35 Krebiz units

Expands

    Star Fleet Battles: Captain's Edition Basic Set

Name: Krebiz-3
Description:
This is the description on the cover:

Includes all the rules needed to for play:
- Krebiz X-1 improved technology
- Krebiz X-1 ship descriptions

Historical background for the Krebiz:
- Two Krebiz campaign games:
- The War of Annihilation, and
- The Krebiz Scavenger Hunt

Technical information including:
- ship descriptions for the Krebiz X-1 units
- Krebiz F&E build costs
- Krebiz campaign notes

Also included: 32 pages of Companion SSDs displaying 35 Krebiz units

Expands

    Star Fleet Battles: Captain's Edition Basic Set

Name: ChessWar
Description:
(from web site)

ChessWar is a strategic game for two players. It is meant to be played on a standard chessboard with standard chess pieces although it can also be used on any kind of battlefield made of squares. It is NOT chess with dice and some extra rules! Instead, it is strategic game played with chess pieces. So, pieces are not automatically captured, some pieces (units) have ranged attacks and all your pieces (units) may move during your turn.

Name: Mindbenders
Description:
From the box - 
First: Read a question
Second: cogitate, digest and discuss
Third: start to pull your hair out, the logical seems illogical, the question seems to have no answer.
Finally: supply an answer or admit defeat
Then: Stare in complete disbelief as the simple answer is read aloud.

Will taunt, tease and torment the way you think!

Contains hundreds of brainteasers, mysteries and puzzles that will BEND your mind!

Name: Pyramid (Battlestar Galactica)
Description:
Pyramid (Battlestar Galactica) is a card game based on the 1970s television series "Battlestar Galactica". It was depicted as leisure activity for the characters in the television show. Later on, rules and decks of pyramid playing cards were made available commercially to fans of the show. Both are currently out of print.
The game uses a 55 count deck of hexagonal cards separated into three kinds of suits and three ranks as well as a 'capstone' card which is used as a wild card. The game is played very similarly to poker. Players are dealt hands and place bets based on how strong their hand is. There is a discard between bets and players reveal their hands to determine the winner of that round.

Winning hands are determined by a number of factors including suit, rank and matching sets. There are approximately fourteen different hand combinations possible in the game. There is no 'end' to the game, players merely quit at their leisure.

The deck consists of 55 hexagonal cards, which is divided into 3 suits: purple, green and orange. Purple ranks highest and orange ranks lowers. The deck also contains a Capstone (*).

Each suit contains:
- 3 First level cards
- 6 Second level cards
- 9 Third level cards

How To Play
Each player is dealt 6 cards. If a player feels a better hand is possible, he may discard up to 4 cards and receive replacements from the dealer. This may only be done once per hand, much the same as "Draw Poker". Players then construct their best possible pyramid and compare to the other player hands to determine the winner.
Ranks of Hands
A pyramid is made up of at least three cards.

1. First level pyramid consist of 2 third level, and 1 second level card.

2. Second level pyramid consist of 3 third level, and 2 second level card.

3. Third level pyramid consist of 3 third level, 2 second level cards, and 1 first level card.

4. Any of the above may be considered "perfect" when all of the cards used are of the same color. ("Perfect" pyramids rank higher than non-perfect pyramids.)

5. If two or more perfect pyramids are the same level, then the highest suit would win. (NOTE: Only perfect pyramids can be ranked by suit; non-perfect pyramids are considered to have no suit.)

6. If two or more pyramids are still equal, then the persons play another hand to decide the winner.


    ) The Capstone can be used in place of the first level card in a Perfect third level pyramid. This is the highest of ALL PYRAMIDS!



        ) The Capstone may also be used as a wild card to replace any card in any pyramid.

Name: Prompt
Description:
Taken from the back of the box:

"Played with gloriously illustrated Character and Prompt cards and a variety of quotations from Shakespeare."

This is a light game of memory and card collection requiring a familiarity with Shakespeare's plays.  It is best suited to play after a dinner party.  Match Prompt and Character cards to your Quotation cards to create sets.  The first to match all their cards into sets wins.  There are 30 sets.

There are two levels of difficulty, which give different methods of play.

The easy method requires players to complete a Shakespeare quote by filling in the missing word(s) on a Quote card, from a Prompt card and matching them to a Character card.  The mechanics of acquiring cards is similar to the children's card game Go Fish.

In the advanced game the mechanics are similar to Happy Families but a good knowledge of Shakespeare is required to get you the cards you desire.  If attempting to obtain a Quote card from another player one has to recite the quote in full and be "Dead Letter Perfect".

In both types of game the mechanics may well be based on children's games, but it is unlikely to appeal to children due to the subject matter.

Name: Set Point Singles and Doubles
Description:
"The only tennis strategy game that plays like the real thing!"

A tennis simulation game, with different boards, but similar mechanics, for playing singles and doubles. The game is played on a board with 81 boxes on each side of the net, grouped in 9 sections. When you play a shot, you call the section (1-9) that you are aiming at, and then roll 2 D6 to see which box in that area it lands in (1, 12 = fault, 2-11 - numbered sectors). If the box is next to a line, 2D6 are rolled to see if the ball is called out. Players can only play a shot if they can move to the ball to play it. The number of boxes that you can move depends on the type of shot played by your opponent (volley, power shot, lob), and where on the court you are. You also can move some boxes after your shot to set for the next one.

The rules do not specify what length of game, etc., to play. Presumably you would decide to play a set, or a tiebreak, or whatever, and use tennis scoring to decide who won.

Name: To Grandma's House We Go!
Description:
From the box:
"A Game designed especially for children to play with their grandparents!"

From the instruction sheet:
"Make your way over the river and through the woods. If you are the first player to reach Grandma's House, you win!"

In this game for children age 3 and up, players take turns drawing cards then following the instructions on the cards to move their cars forward along the board to Grandma's House. Cards consist of two types:

Color/shape cards - Move the car forward to the first space matching the color and shape on the card.

Word cards - Kids draw the card, an adult reads it aloud, then the kid follows the instruction or answers the question on the card (things like smile or give another player a hug or answer "What's your middle name?", "Who's your best friend?", etc.) The card then instructs the player to move the car or draw another card.

The first player to reach the end of the board (Grandma's House) wins.

Components:
1 Instruction Sheet
1 Gameboard
4 Plastic Cars
6 Cardboard Kid Figures for the Cars
1 Grandma's House
66 Cards

Name: Flivver Game
Description:
The game box is 6 1/4" by 4 1/4" and 1" deep.

The box contains:

Four die cast touring cars
A spinning wheel board (to generate random movement number)
A one page rulebook.

The game is about racing in Ford "Flivver" (Model T?) cars.

The game is played by spinning the "rear wheel of the Ford indicator" and moving the indicated number of spaces.  Text on various spaces affect the players moves.  First player to reach home by exact count wins.

NOTE: No car may pass another on the Narrow Road sections of the board, and only one car may occupy a space in these sections. Two players may occupy a space on the rest of the board, but if a third player's spin takes him to the same space he loses his turn. If a spin takes a player to the space marked "spin front wheel" he is entitled to spin the front wheel of the Ford indicator. If this spin lands on the "5", he can move 5 spaces. If it lands on any of the blank spaces, his turn ends.

Name: Cup Skipper
Description: "The match race sailing game" consists of 2 to 4 yachts sailing around a course set out at the beginning of the game.  The game was developed to "to help improve interest and understanding of match racing" and consists of throwing a dice and moving pegs (yachts) up and down a board following yachting rules without incurring penalties.

Name: Ava
Description:
Ava comes with a wooden gameboard displaying a hexagon divided into small triangles and 59 colored stones in black, white and red.

The players try to achieve one of the three winning conditions using 6 stones: 6 stones in a row, 6 stones creating a triangle or 6 stones creating a hexagon.

Game has placement and movement phases.

Name: Die! Die! Bang!
Description:
Each player is one of five Alliances (a criminal organization) and undertakes various crimes in order to receive a reward.

Each player has a scoreboard (which records their 'crime', 'information', 'battle' and 'reward'), Alliance card and Karma table.  A Boss is selected (the player with the most criminal convictions!).  The Boss selects three Karma cards, takes one and passes two to the player on the left.  The process is repeated until all players have two cards.  All players roll the dice and place a mission card in the corresponding numbered area.

Players place Alliance cards next to the missions they select.  Where more than one player attempts a mission they simultaneously show a thumbs up/thumbs down sign to declare whether they will co-operate or fight.  If players co-operate they divide the reward.  If players fight they divide into the groups, all who voted to co-operate (if any) are one group, fighters become separate groups of one.  Battles are determines by dice roll plus Battle influence.  The winner takes the reward.  The first player to collect ten rewards wins the game.

Name: A Bloody Business: The Battle of Hue, 1968
Description:
(From the game rules:)

A Bloody Business: the Battle for Hue, Tet 1968 covers the attack on the old Imperial capital of Hue by forces of the North Vietnamese Army and South Vietnamese insurgents of the National Liberation Front during the Tet Offensive. The Communist forces hoped a popular uprising by the "oppressed" people in South Vietnam would lead to a general uprising and overthrow of the "puppet" regime supported by the United States. 
The city of Hue was the only city to be completely occupied by the communist forces during the massive offensive, and was the scene of violent and close-quarter fighting that waged for nearly a month, from January 31st to February 25th, 1968. The general uprising never occurred, and in fact the communist's disappointment led to atrocities when they massacred hundreds of "collaborators" after they took control. The fighting to retake control of the city and oust the NVA and VC devastated the city and Imperial Palace, symbolizing the tragic and confused nature of the war.

Players are cast in the roles of the commanders of each side's forces. Both players will have capabilities to inflict harm upon their opponent, while also having liabilities to protect. Contestants will be challenged to do as well, or better than, their historical counterparts.

Game Scale: The map scale is about 350-400 yards per inch. 
Each combat unit represents a platoon (25 to 30 men, 2 tanks or 6 APCs (Armored Personnel Carriers) and artillery batteries (M-109, Katyusha rockets, and mortars). 
A game turn represents 2-3 days of time.

Name: Cooperation
Description:
The goal of this little roll-and-move game is for players to work together to make it to the finish line.  Along the way, they have some choices to make as to whether to which path to take and whether to remain together or to go their separate ways.  Depending upon where they land, they can draw Gold, Disaster, or Frustration cards that affect them depending on whether they are still with their partner.  The goal of the game is to be the player holding the least chips when the finish line is reached.

Per manufacturer advertisement:

"Cooperation? is a hilarious experience. It lets you scheme, practice being crafty, have fun with disaster. Once you've betrayed your partner - and you probably will - watch out! If you choose to cooperate . . . beware!

Cooperation? stands unique among games. It's aim is to beat you, and, since all players are facing this same obstacle, someone has to be the winner.

Score Cooperation? high in entertainment. It's the kind of a game you will want to bring out at a party . . . and all ages can play. Four to six players, in teams of two. You will experience hours of fun and relaxation. "

Name: Samurai Sunset: Triumph of the Will
Description:
In this alternate history, Nazi Germany and Japan who won WW II have started WWW III in 1948.

In this game, Germany invades Japan.
The German have super elite troops such as some of the best and most well known panzerdivisions, heavy Maus tank units, US Marines, ME-262 fighters, the Kriegsmarine, Rommel, Guderian and Von Manstein and others. The Japanese have the numbers, but also Samurai divisions, Kamikaze, the Emperor.

The game uses the rules, map and many units of Samurai Sunset. It also introduces new units and additional rules.

Published in Command Magazine #5

Name: Problems and Programmers
Description:
Problems and Programmers is an educational software engineering card game. Featuring over 120 unique cards, it is intended to simulate the software development process from conception to completion. The game's players compete to finish their projects while avoiding the potential pitfalls of software engineering. These players will quickly learn that the strategies that will let them win the game are the same that will help them in the real world.

Complete rules, as well as files for creating all of the game components, previously could be found at http://www.problemsandprogrammers.com/

Name: Beat The Bookie Race Odds Game
Description:
A contemporary betting game consisting of 52 standard size playing cards:
8 horse cards and 44 odds cards


The rules description reads
"Given various odds the bookie chooses which horse will win
and the other players bet on what they think has been chosen.

The bookie then reveals the horse chosen and settles the bets accordingly. The objective of the game is to place bets on the horse the bookmaker picks."

Name: Bookie: The Card Game
Description:
A betting game published by Central News Ltd.,London.

The game consisted of:
52 standard size playing cards,
6 horse "Runner" cards with seven numbers for
each named horse, 
4 special set-up cards.

The description from the rules reads:
"The first horse to reach a position in line with the first card marking the course is the winner. The next horse to arrive achieves a "place" and wins one-third the odds offered by the Bookie...

Practice will quickly determine the possible odds to be laid.

These will range between 6 to 1 and 50 to 1, or possibly more."

Name: CHECKCHESS RoundBoard
Description:
CHECKCHESS RoundBoard contains standard sets of chessmen and checkers, but as the name implies the real star is the game board.  The circular board consists of eight rings of eight spaces each.  Each ring corresponds to one of the eight ranks on a standard chessboard, and each radially-aligned group of spaces corresponds to a file.  (They're even labeled 1-8 from outside to inside and a-h counterclockwise, and the rulebook calls them "squares" despite their curved shape.)

The pieces are set up with one player on the outside of the circle facing in and the other in the center facing out (but otherwise exactly as in ordinary chess or checkers) and the rules of those games are unchanged except that file "a" and file "h" are considered adjacent for the purposes of movement.  This is equivalent to the variant in which pieces are allowed to move off the right side of a square chess board onto the left and vice versa, but on the round board all legally-adjacent spaces are also physically adjacent.

From the designer's notes included with the game:

"An engineer by profession, I have always had a fascination with the game of chess.  As a member of my high school chess team, I played hooky from school to strengthen my game.

"In the 1960's the concept of a round board interested me as a novelty.  However, some 25 years later I made a serious study of that novelty and concluded that the round board is a major evolutionary advancement in the games of chess and checkers.  I hope you share my belief and enjoy your games on CHECKCHESS RoundBoard(TM)."

Name: Cityism  -- The Austin Trivia Board Game
Description:
What is cityism?

Webster's says nationalism is loyalty to a nation, especially its culture.  So cityism is loyalty to a city, especially its culture.
     All cities have cool things.  But you have to live there to appreciate some of them. Who but Austinites would delight in Spamorama or Eyeore's Birthday Party?

All questions are about Austin.

Name: Cluster
Description:
Cluster's playing board consists of forty six holes, of which twenty four are shallow and twenty two are deep.  There are sixteen playing pieces, eight white and eight black. Within the set of eight there are four short pieces and four long ones. If a long piece is placed in a deep hole and short piece in a shallow hole, the the tops of the two pieces will be level.

The object of the game is to form a "cluster" before your opponent does. A cluster is when all of your pieces (one player has white and the other black) are in a group all next to each other and all of the tops of the pieces are at the same level.

Name: Pentagon: The Marble Game of the 70's
Description:
Players set their marbles up on the interior or exterior pentagon.  From there, you attempt to move one at a time taking turns to get to the person's other pentagon (e.g. interior tries to get to the exterior).  You can jump when you are next to another's marble and capture it.  First one to get all their remaining marbles to the inside wins as long as he has as many marbles the other person.

Nice wooden board and marbles for bits...

Name: Toggle Logic
Description:
Toggle Logic is the umbrella game for two variants, Batel and BaoWei. Played on a standard chessboard, each piece has two distinct sides. Batel is a race to be the first to occupy your opponent's home row. BaoWei has a capture mechanic, with randomness increased through the use of dice.

The Toggle Logic set comes in a 6" closed tube with enough two-colored pieces for either variant. The tube includes a cloth screen-print playing board, two-colored pieces, dice, and instructions. It is self-published by the designer in Lawrence, Kansas.

Name: Kriegspiel
Description:
Invented in 1899 by Henry Michael Temple, this chess variant is played by 2 players but requires a third person to act as an umpire. Essentially, players only know the positions of their own pieces and have to make inferences based on what the umpire tells them (for example, that a move is impossible, or a capture has been made on a specific square).

According to The Encyclopedia of Chess Variants (D.B. Pritchard, 1994) alternative names are Screen Chess, War-Chess and Commando Chess.

David Li's book Kriegspiel: Chess Under Uncertainty (1994) provides a set of rules and some sample games.

Name: The Money Game
Description:
A boxed set of cards used in three games intended to explain, and educate about, monetary and banking systems.

The box contains two sets of cards - one set represents machine parts, the other bank notes - and score sheets.

Both games are based around the premise of an engineer shipwrecked on an island - he has a limited source of gold.  The islanders have machine parts from an earlier shipwreck.

In the first game one player represents the engineer and the others the islanders.  The engineer wants to buy machine parts (collect complete sets), but the cost of buying parts goes up the more he buys in one go from any one islander.  The islanders want to get as much of his money as they can, and one of them can win by 'breaking' the engineers bank by holding more notes than he can cover with his supply of gold.

In the second game the islanders are purchasing goods produced by the engineer by bidding. In this game the engineer does not score, but merely acts as banker.  The winner is the islander who has managed to accumulate the most merchandise

The third game represents an experiment by our one-time shipwrecked engineer, now financier.  He has a contract with the islanders by which he pays £200.00 for a complete eneterprise (set of machine cards). To ensure that they can find and supply the complete enterprises to him he lends them money which they can use to bargain with amongst themselves.
This game is meant to illustrate the mutual indebtedness which is the characteristic of banking, and involves considerable amounts of maths.

The Money Game was first published in 1928 but Angell included a 1912 copyright in the game on the grounds that he had first conceived it before the war. The game was presented as a book with the the cards and money in boxed compartments at the back of the book. It included many quotes from people recommending it. Though Angell worked on the game subsequently he never published a subsequent version.

Name: Dora the Explorer: Picnic Fiesta
Description:
Dora is planning a picnic with her friends.  You have to flick their picnic favorites to them before Swiper the Fox pops up and stops you.  Each of the picnic favorites is on plastic disc which you attempt to shoot out with the right amount of force and at the right angle to get it to land in an area where it can score.

Swiper is a pop up figure who will activate after 60 seconds, after which it's impossible to hit the target.

You can play in competition with other players and there is a second level where you have to shoot the discs in the right order and at set targets.

Name: Triplexity
Description:
Triplexity, and its sisters Triple-Triplexity, Duple, Double-Duple, and Monotony, were created in 1984. The designers had been playing Go, but couldn't find a balanced way to play three. So they created a grid composed of triangles laid into a hexagon shape, and designed Triplexity. Stones are played on the intersections of the grid-lines. The object of the game is to be the first player to get five or more stones in a row. Opponents' rows may be blocked, or their stones may be captured.

The designers describe the game:

"Each player must try to establish a winning position with a strong but flexible offense, while hindering their opponents' play. Every placement of a game stone on the grid increases the possibilities and the complexities.

"It is an aggressive, every one for themselves game; defensive alliances are short lived and not to be trusted, the timid player rarely comes out on top with each game taking generally not more than 10-15 minutes to play."

"Offense writ large should be your plan; defense will follow from a superior offense. Quick moves will facilitate play and learning of the games."

From the original game manual (Copyright 1984):

"TRIPLEXITY(TM) is a unique system that allows the playing of several different games. Presented here are the two best, TRIPLEXITY(TM) and DUPLE(TM).  Although these two games are played with the same gemstones and on the same grid, they are significantly different, each involving different dynamics and requiring different strategies.
TRIPLEXITY(TM) (a game for 3) and its partner game TRIPLE-TRIPLEXITY(TM) (a game for 6) offer something we have not seen before, a pure strategy game involving three adversaries.
Each player must try to establish a winning position with a strong but flexible offense, while hindering their opponents play.  Every placement of a gemstone on the grid increases the possibilities and the complexities. As your skill improves you will realize more the dimensions and subtleties of this game.
TRIPLEXITY(TM) is a surprisingly fast paced game.
It is an aggressive , every one for themselves game, defensive alliances are short-lived and not to be trusted, the timid player rarely comes out on top with each game typically taking no more than 10-15 minutes to play.  TRIPLEXITY(TM) fits in well with the fast pace of our modern society, and by its nature is an appropriate metaphor for our times.
DUPLE(TM) (a game for 2) and its partner game DOUBLE-DUPLE(TM) (a game for 4) are closer to the traditional strategy game, in that the third adversary, the wild card of TRIPLEXITY(TM), is missing. But the unique dynamics of the TRIPLEXITY(TM) grid remain, as well as the added dimension of playing two stones per turn.  This simple difference alters the strategy significantly.
In DUPLE(TM), even more so than in TRIPLEXITY(TM), hesitating to seize control can cost you the game.  Yet going for control too soon can be disastrous.  DUPLE(TM) is a game of timing as much as it is a game of position.
From the feedback we have gotten we have found some people preferred one game over the other.  We find comparisons difficult because of the unique qualities of each game.  
TRIPLEXITY(TM) and DUPLE(TM), along with their partner games TRIPLE-TRIPLEXITY(TM) and DOUBLE-DUPLE(TM) as well as MONOTONY(TM) (a game for 1), cover such a range of possibilities that a truly excellent strategy game can be played with any number of people up to and including 6.  (Except 5, we have never been able to get this number to work well.  If you come up with something, we would enjoy learning how to play it!)
TRIPLEXITY(TM) and DUPLE(TM) offers what we think are two of the best strategy games to have been discovered in a very long time.  If you are only an occasional game player we think you will find this to be one of the most fun and challenging game sets you have ever owned. If you are a frequent strategy game player then this one is a must and you will find, as we have, that it is a joy to play.
In keeping with the quality of the games themselves we endeavored to bring them to you in a quality form. This is not cardboard and plastic and with proper care, your game should last you many years.
Have fun."

"HISTORY: In early July, the summer of 1984, John and I were playing Go - the ancient game of territory capturing and strategy of lines. While we were playing Mario came over so we decided to see if the game could be played by three. Well we played our version of Go-moku-narrabe and had a measure of success and fun. However, we were not very satisfied.  So we discussed rule modifications and also the idea of a different playing grid. We were all in agreement over this advance.
After this the rules just seemed to come with the playoff this new game on our grid.
The snatch and snug came as developments of our play over the next several weeks.  I remember suggesting the snatch and we were all in agreement, but thought it would have very few applications.  Then Mario said why not, since w e were able to capture a stone, be able to secure a point.  We all agreed on this advance and the game was set.  But as our skills grew we got closer to the edge and John did his blitz edge game on us.  Well, we are all wiser now.
So when we got tired of sharing the world championship game among ourselves we decided to offer you these games of which we are so fond."

Name: GO mental SACRAmental
Description:
From the Publisher:

"GO mental® SACRAmental   is more than just a Bible version of the classic game!  It brings together a cunning compilation of scripture and community, sacred purpose and secular practice in a spiritually focused family board game that embraces everything from Holy writ to church history; from public veneration to private contemplation; from the specifics of observant belief to religious experience in the everyday world.
 As with the entire GO mental® family, GO mental® SACRAmental is more than just a game.  It’s a mini encyclopedia of information.  Complete with extensive chapter and verse references, historical, geographical and scriptural information on a wide range of the world’s religions, GO mental® SACRAmental doesn’t just give you the answer.  GO mental® SACRAmental tells you why  it’s the answer."

Name: GO mental FUNDAmental
Description:
From the Publisher:

"GO mental® FUNDAmental can be played either as a stand-alone game or in conjunction with the classic GO mental® so that younger and older players can play, learn and enjoy together!  Whether you’re a kid or just a kid at heart, no one’s left out.  And, with the Junior Rules, players even younger than 8 can join in with cards you design especially for them! With GO mental® FUNDAmental the entire family can GO mental® at the same time!
 Plus, with questions carefully tailored not just towards what kids know or should know but also to what kids care about, with GO mental® FUNDAmental, the interest never flags.  It mixes a cunning kaleidoscope of education and entertainment, school stuff and cool stuff, in a constantly changing flurry of facts and fun from math and music to Mary Kate and Ashley; from science and sports to SpongeBob and Spiderman; from geography and history to Star Wars and dinosaurs; from basic biology to Bob the Builder."

Name: QQChess
Description: QQChess, a.k.a. Quad Quest Chess, is a chess hybrid/variant designed to accommodate 2, 3 or 4 players that combines features of international and Chinese chess. Knights can bounce off pieces of their own type to capture an opponent's piece. What's more, you can choose one of the opponent's pieces and have it become a traitor for your side.

Name: Midevil II: Castle Chaos
Description:
Well, it wasn't as easy as you expected. You were told that the only way to get back to the present was to go to the graveyard, find the Necronomicon and take it to the altar. Yeah, right! Now they want you to bring it back here! Of course, you do get to kick some Skeleton butt on the way and that's always fun!

Part of the MidEvil/Zombies!!! series

Expands:

    MidEvil

Name: Pictionary: After Dinner Mint Edition
Description:
Like the classic Pictionary game. The team must guess the word that their team mate is drawing.
The spin is that the game is played with mints - each correct guess earns the team a chocolate. The team with the most chocolates at the end wins.

Name: Pro Wrestler
Description:
Detailed Wrestling sports simulation.

Contains 16 fictional wrestlers all with differing abilities.  Create your own match-ups, even create your own wrestlers!.  Play tag-team matches, battle royals, cage matches etc.  Develop skills and wrestler histories.  Fun for tournament play.

Name: APBA Major League Baseball Master Game
Description: A baseball simulation game, which includes dice, markers, and a booklet with charts for each of 8 base situations (bases empty to bases loaded), rare plays, base stealing, base advancement. Players roll dice and refer to charts for results.

Name: Celebrity Turds
Description:
Big name stars earn more in a couple of hours than most of us do in a year. And the media never let’s us forget how luxurious their lives are. We offer you a different view... we've drawn them as poo! Are you ready to have a little giggle at the overblown world of celebrities?

Players take on the role of movie director. They must create poker style combinations of celebrity turds to star in movies with a fecal theme. The player who scores the most points by making the most valuable movies wins the game.

It’s easy to learn and easy to play. Just deal the cards for guaranteed fun and laughter.

Name: Lil Squirt
Description:
A children's dexterity game from the 1950s that is very similar to the game "Tickle Bee".  The display is mounted on a yellow board and comes with a "magnetic skunk chaser".
A player must navigate the skunk through the simple maze under such red-colored objects as a ladder, a piper, a pig, a drum, a rock tunnel, a covered bridge, a haunted house, a drain pipe, or an old stump.  However, one should be careful to not to get too close, or the skunk will "spray" (lift up off the board and touch the wand).

"Lil Squirt likes to run and play but don't get too close, or he will spray."

Name: Heraldic
Description:
A game of matching and capturing; a Bezique-based game - with original elements and developments.

HERALDIC is uniquely designed to create all the problems of Bezique with a pack of only 48 cards. The card designs are based on traditional animals of the hunt and mythical creatures.

Players capture the high-scoring cards in whist-style tricks, then score various combinations of cards on the table and across the table. First player to 1000 points is the winner. Unlike bezique it works well with 2, 3 or 4 players.

Name: Říše snů
Description:
In the game players represent a fantastic creature that enters the realm of dreams. They try to ally powerful beings by completing their quests. Every player has a set of few special cards that can be placed on a gameboard to slow down the progress of other players. In fact it's a fantasy adventure board game where characters are moving around the gameboard, completing tasks and killing creeps.

The played time is somewhere between 30-90 based on the picked mission at the beginning of the game. There are plenty of different missions to choose from, and they have a big impact on the game system as well. You can choose cooperative mission where players play together, or PvP mission, or even solitaire.

Name: Bible Cubes
Description:
12 wooden cubes labeled with books of the Bible.
Each of the 66 books of the Bible are represented on 11 of the cubes, while the 12th is labeled with Creation, Ten Commandments, Beatitudes, Church Begins, and two blank sides that represent 'wild cards'.

Players roll the cubes and attempt to identify consecutive books.  Two consecutive books score 1 point; three score 2 points; etc.  The first and last books of the Old and New Testament are bonus books that score 2 points regardless of matches, and the events on the 12th cube score 5 points if you can match them to the book in which they occur.  First player to 40 points wins.

A number of other games could be played with these cubes, but these are the rules as stated.

Name: The Game of Peter Rabbit
Description:
First made available to the public in 1995, the design for the game was originally submitted by Beatrix Potter to her publisher, Frederick Warne, in 1904.

The game board - a reproduction of Potter's watercolor original - represents Mr. McGregor's garden, with 12 key points of interest from the book marked on the map. Peter must enter at the gate, visit each of the twelve points (leaving a brass button behind to mark his visit), and then exit through the gate. He is pursued in this endeavor by Mr. McGregor who is restricted to moving on the garden pathways, unlike Peter. Mr. McGregor wins by catching Peter. Should Mr. McGregor choose to guard the gate rather than pursue Peter, an alternative escape route becomes available.

The game includes copies of Potter's handwritten rules for the game (both original and revised) and her original letter to the publisher introducing and endorsing the game - all from 1904 - as well as a recreation of her 1893 letter to 5-year-old Noel Moore, in which she first told and drew "The Tale of Peter Rabbit."

Name: Summ herum
Description:
Frederic is a really pesky frog! What he likes most is to tease the little bees, as they fly across his pond. With his magnetic sticky tongue, he catches the busy nectar gathering animals. Which smart bee, with some luck and tactical thinking, will sneak past the frog?

Ages 4 and up

Name: "In Pursuit of Par" TPC Sawgrass Edition
Description:
"In Pursuit of Par" is designed to simulate a game of golf among players of equal ability.  A player's success depends on club selection, aim, and luck of the dice.

This edition is played on four double-sided game boards representing the Stadium Course at TPC at Sawgrass, Ponte Vedra, Florida.  Each hole has four tee boxes, representing The Players' Championship Tees, two sets of Men's Tees, and the Ladies' Tees.

Name: Big League Baseball Card Game
Description: This game comes with 36 cards, instructions, and four score sheets. Each laminated card features black ink line drawings depicting the players, uniforms, and equipment of the era (1949) plus and possible play outcomes, which include home run, triple, double, singles, sacrifice, error, strike outs, walks, stolen base, passed ball, pickoff, and doubleplay.

Name: Snakes in the Grass
Description:
The object is to scoop up eggs (colored marbles) on the snake's "tongue" and put them on the holders in the snake's "nest."  The eggs are different colors, with each color having  points assigned to them.

There is a handicap system using discs on each snake handle indicating how far down the snake's body the player may hold the snake. The closer to the tongue that grip is permitted, the easier the game play.

Name: Aloha: Le jeu rituel des archipels
Description:
Each player represents a tribe who races to bring their tiki across the archipelago in order to name the next king. Players move around their (or sometime, their opponents') pirogues across an ocean of tiles with special effects to bring their tiki to an opponent's island. The game comes with two sets of rules, one familial (basic) and one expert (advanced). Even though the game and the rules are in French, the components are multilingual.

Material :
32 ocean tiles
16 pirogues
4 tikis
4 beaches
12 markers
2 rulebooks

Name: Mickey Mouse Rickety Bridge Game
Description:
Walt Disney board game dominated by a central three-dimensional die-cut bridge with four movable pylons.

Players must transport two monkeys of their color to the finishing area on the other side of the river, so three separate journeys must be made as the monkeys cannot be carried together.  Players may elect to take the long, safer route around the edge of the board or they may take the shorter route & attempt to cross the bridge.

Gameplay is directed by a spinner, which has 5 divisions (1-4 movement & a broken plank).  If the plank is spun, one of the pylons supporting the bridge is removed.  Pieces that fall into the river from removal of pylons are placed on a special log square on the longer outer path.

The first player to get both of their monkeys to the finishing area is the winner.

Name: Rattle Me Bones
Description:
A spring-loaded dexterity game where players attempt to carefully remove various objects from a motorized, battery-operated, glow-in-the-dark skeleton without setting off the mechanism that causes the skeleton to shake & vibrate.

A spinner directs gameplay and indicates the appropriate piece which the player must attempt to remove from the skeleton on that turn.  If the vibrating mechanism is tripped the player must replace the object that was spun.

When all objects have been removed from the skeleton the game is over.  The winner is the player who removed the most objects from the skeleton successfully.

Name: Suck My Marbles
Description:
Players must select witty ways to describe the crazy stuff people love and hate. It's easy to learn and easy to play. Just deal the cards for guaranteed fun and laughter.

For 3 to 8 adult players.

Name: Wacky Races
Description: The game is a variant on Chutes and Ladders set in the Wacky Races environment. Players roll dice to move generic plastic cars (not miniatures/replicas) around the board, which represents a racing track with a number of side routes which can bring you from being in the lead to being well behind if you are side-tracked. Cards are drawn from a stack featuring images of Wacky Races cars. Players must collect four car cards and land exactly on the finish line to win (which means that you usually complete several circuits of the track). Car cards can be lost if players draw the Mean Machine card. The stack of draw cards also feature event descriptions and commands which make you miss turns, take alternate routes, or go forward or backward several spaces.

Name: Scrabble People
Description: Each player is dealt four cards and must have only four cards in his or her hand at the end of each turn.  The remaining cards form a "pick-up" pile with the top card turned over to form the beginning of a "put-down" pile.  A player selects a card from either of the two piles and discards a card onto the "put-down" pile.  Sir Scrabble and Muddler cards cannot be taken.  A Sir Scrabble card can be discarded to take another turn.  Conversely, a Muddler card can be discarded so that the next player will have to lose a turn.  The "put-down" pile should be turned over, if all of the cards from the "pick-up" pile have been used.  The winner is one who collects four cards of any of the following: queen, jeweler, baby, librarian, waiter, or zookeeper.

Name: Legend of the Moonsword
Description: In this game based loosely on the world of Grimms' fairy tales, each player takes on the role of a Child, Damsel, Man or Beast on a quest to find the legendary Moonsword in order to defend a fantasy kingdom.  Different character types have different strengths and weaknesses, and each player starts with a different Quest card explaining exactly what objects and locations must be found in order to obtain the Moonsword.  Players then wander the board battling monsters, acquiring objects and drawing random event cards.  The first person to meet the quest goals, obtain the Moonsword, and find their hidden magic gate is the winner.

Name: Disney's Gummi Bears Giant Card Game
Description: The 40 cards are placed face down.  Players take turn revealing four cards.  If two cards match, the two matching cards are placed next to the player; if three cards match, two of the matching cards are placed next to the player; and if four cards match, the player automatically wins the game.  If a player uncovers two Duke Igthorn cards, that player may steal a pair for any player and add them to his or her pile with the two Duke cards.  The winner is the player with the most pairs when all the cards have been revealed.

Name: Star Games
Description:
This vintage constellation card set game by the Naturegraph Company of San Marin, California, comes with four different games.

1.  Guess the Constellation:  Teams attempt to guess the names of the constellation cards held by a game leader.

2.  Deal Constellations:  Two or more players attempt to guess the names of the constellations on other players cards.

3.  Map the Sky:  Players attempt to place cards in relation to the north star.  (A star map is typically needed.)

4.  Star Relay:  Two teams with flashlights attempt to locate the most constellations.

(Perhaps holes could be poked through copies of the cards in order to project the constellation onto an inside wall?)

The game comes with cards representing 30 constellations that are visible in the Northern Hemisphere.  A 1956 planet guide was also included.

The game was adapted from the book, The Stars, by H. A. Rey (Houghton-Mifflin Co., 1952) with permission from the author and publishers.

Name: ZIN
Description:
This two player abstract strategy game is played on a standard eight by eight Chess board, though the board is oriented diagonally.  Each player is given an equal force of pieces in a different color -- five tall hexagonal Wall pieces, ten numbered Zin pieces (four 2's plus one of each of the other numbers between 1 and 7), and an unnumbered Rogue Zin piece.  All of the Zin pieces are portrayed as stacks of four hexagons of decreasing size.

The object of the game is to capture the opponent's 1-Zin piece.

The board is set up with the player's numbered Zin pieces behind a row of five Walls, with the Rogue Zin to the player's left near the center of the board.  Players take turns moving one piece per turn, starting with the Black player.  All pieces move in a straight line through unoccupied spaces, horizontally, vertically or diagonally.  Zin pieces may end their turn on top of Wall pieces.  The numbers on standard Zin pieces determine the maximum number of spaces that they may move.  Rogue Zins can move up to three spaces and have some special powers which make them more flexible than standard Zins.  Walls move only one space per turn, and only if they are unoccupied.

Pieces are captured by being landed on by an opponent's piece.  Regular Zins may only capture opponents on the same or a lower plane (i.e. they can't capture an opponent on a wall if they are on the surface of the board).  Walls may be either captured or landed upon at the player's discretion.  They may also be promoted to other types of pieces of they reach the opponent's side of the board.  In capturing, as in movement, Rogue Zins have some special rules which make them more powerful than their standard counterparts.

As a special gimmick, the game includes a special extra 1-Zin piece called a zinK featuring a serial number sticker on the bottom.  Players are encouraged to play special games where the winner keeps the opponent's zinK, with the ultimate goal to collect a zinK with as low a serial number as possible.

Name: Illuminati: Bavarian Fire Drill
Description:
(From the Warehouse 23 website)

Bavarian Fire Drill is the long-awaited expansion for Illuminati. It adds 110 new cards illustrated (mostly) by the redoubtable Dan Smith.

Control new and terrifying groups like Bloggers, Reality Shows, and Intelligent Design. Will you use Embedded Reporters and FEMA to destroy the Webcams, or will you be defeated by Bird Flu and Bobbleheads? Fans of the mega-hit INWO will recall the Deprogrammers and Science Alarmists, as well as more of the best groups from the best-selling conspiracy CCG.

BFD also introduces a new kind of card: Artifacts! Some are magical, some are technological, some are just . . . strange. But all of them give their owners an unfair advantage in the struggle for world domination. Hitler's Brain, the Spear of Longinus, the Screaming Meme – and these are just the beginning.

Bavarian Fire Drill. You know what it means, but your cover demands you pretend not to . . .

The German Pegasus edition contains 120 cards: 108 translated English cards, 10 additional group cards and two blanks.

Expands:

    Illuminati

Name: Nautical Trivia
Description:
From the designer's site:

A roll of the cube determines whether the driving force that propels your boat will be by knowledge or by chance. Nautical Trivia's challenging questions (many in true/false and multiple choice format) will test your knowledge of nautical history, the America's Cup, historic lighthouses, navigation, boating safety, famous shipwrecks, infamous pirates and world geography. The "Jolly Roger" and "Treasure Chest" chance cards are designed to impact the outcome of the race with unpredictable variables based on actual sailing situations. Just when you thought it was smooth sailing, a "Jolly Roger" hurricane card blows all boats off course out to open sea!!!

Name: HoverTank: Death and Destruction in the fight for Oil in 2022
Description:
"With the discoveries of huge Oil and Gas reserves under the Caspian Sea region, the multitude of affected nations realized that this is their golden opportunity for hard currency with and the power it brings.  Diplomacy fails as a viable option in 2022..."

Tube game.  4 maps (back to back), 7 six-sided dice, 36 plastic miniature units (hovertanks, tanks, helicopters, etc.).

Simple wargame with 9 types of terrain and 8 types of units.

Object of the game is to destroy opponents airbase, then take the major city on the map.

Name: Silly Sandwiches
Description:
Players have to memorize which ingredients are between slices of toast and in which order. When a player remembers wrongly he helps his opponents, but when he remembers correctly he gets the toasts for himself. The player having the most ingredient cards in the end is the winner.

From the back of the box:

The craziest memory game ever! You much remember all the unusual ingredients used in the sandwich, in the correct order, to score points. The thicker the sandwich, the more points you get!

Name: Tuntematon Sotilas
Description: A Finnish trivia game about one of the most acclaimed Finnish novels, Tuntematon Sotilas (Unknown Soldier) and the 2 movies it has spawned. The story on hand is about war and soldiers in the Finnish Continuation War against the Soviet Union during WWII. The game has been published to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the 1st of the movies which is to this day still shown in Finnish public television every Independence Day, 6th of December. There are 1000 questions containing a lot of overall Finnish military history.

Name: Seitsemän Päivää Julkkistietopeli
Description: A Finnish trivia game about celebrities. To win you'll have to know all the latest rumors, gossip and scandals seen on the pages of a popular Finnish weekly scandal-magazine "Seitsemän Päivää". The name of the magazine would translate into English as "Seven Days"

Name: Winkers the game
Description: "The Strategy Game you can lose in a wink!" a 19 space hex board, 20 neutral checkers that can only be played on the board, 10 winks each that can only be played on a checker. 3 in a row wins.

Name: Bible Lotto
Description: In Bible Lotto, players are asked questions about bible characters.  Whoever has a spot on his lotto card for the bible character in question fills in that spot with the question card.  Players try to fill up their lotto cards.

Name: Math Magic
Description:
Math Magic 
A strategic board game which echoes a domino style format. 
Each tile is sectioned into quarter, colored triangles, with each color representing a math operation. Red for division, green for multiplication, blue for subtraction and yellow for addition. Players, in turn, match a tile to an existing one, trying to outsource their opponent. While 
division and subtraction earn fewer points, any remaining tiles will be subtracted at the end of the game. 
Players: 1 - 4 
Ages 10+ 
Contents: 
Gameboard, 4 tile holders, reproducible score sheets, 84 tiles, tile pouch, instructions

Available for sale at:
http://www.educatorsoutlet.com/2005/webcatalog.php?showpage=15&showletter=P
[dead link]

Name: Sinbad
Description:
Sinbad
A game of excitement and adventure from the Columbia Pictures "Sinbad" Movies

Players start at Bagdad and each select one of the four voyages: "Gulf of Fear", "Bay of Horrors", "Sea of Monsters", or "Impossible Ocean". Each sea has four islands guarded by monsters. Three treasures are placed on each island.

Players use a spinner to move around the four islands. When landing on the right spot, they may also spin to get treasure. Guess the spin means success. Some spots give the opportunity for treasure, but also mean a monster must be fought. Other spots move the player back a space.

When one player completes his journey, the round ends and whoever has the most treasure wins. Players then change voyages and continue until each player has made all four voyages. The player with the highest treasure score after all four voyages wins the game.

Name: Rayatso
Description: A two-player card game where the idea is to build chains from the same colored cards. The winner is the player who is able to build a continuous chain from the edge of the playing field to the other edge.

Name: Roy Morgan's Ultimate Survey
Description:
A game which aims to educate about the value of collecting social and consumer statistics.
The object is to earn the most votes by guessing opponents' responses to questions posed on the survey cards. When a player reaches the finish all players' vote are tallied, the winner having the most votes.
Players gain votes from betting on opponents' survey answers. When a player lands on a poll space he undertakes a survey, picks up a survey question card, reads it aloud and secretly chooses a response card (1,2 or 3) corresponding to the multiple choice answers provided. The other players each then choose a response card which they think the survey player has chosen and wager on their response being correct. There is no limit to the wager. Players who guess correctly double their wagers. Players who incorrectly guess lose their wager. The survey player receives 10 votes for each player who correctly guesses their answer.
Players also gain and lose votes from the action spaces on the board.

Name: Direct Conflict in Dimension Six
Description:
"Master the aspects of a parallel dimension in order to overwhelm your opponent's interstellar empire.  A two player game for ages twelve to adult."  (box cover)

There are two game boards - one representing "normal" space and one representing "dimension 6".  Both represent the same physical space but ships move differently in the 2 dimensions.

240 counters
Families: Players: Wargames with Rules Supporting Only Two Players

Name: Knock The Clock
Description:
The game comes with a deck of 25 cards (4 colors numbered 1-6 & a joker) plus a large comical plastic clock which serves as a timer and scoring device.  The full deck is only required for a full complement of players.

All players are dealt 4 cards, except the player to the dealer's left who receives 5 (the 'captain').  The clock is wound and held until the deal is completed; the timer is then released.  Cards are passed to the left on the direction of the captain until one player has four-of-a-kind; this player places their cards on the table.

As soon as this happens, opponents do the same, regardless of cards held at the time.  This procedure mimics 'snap' and the player whose hand is on top also stops the clock timer and scores the amount indicated on the dial.

When any one player reaches 25 points, the game is over.  The winner is the player with the lowest score at that time.

Name: The New Game of Busy Bees
Description:
Busy Bees is a children's game played on a honeycombed (hex) board with flowers on each outer edge.  Each players starts with a bee in the center position and then rolls two dice.  The hex space has numbers at the outer edge and the player must move through a line that matches the number thrown on on of the dice.  This is then repeated for the number shown on the second die.

The object of the game is for each player to visit each flower once (and collect a colored hive for doing so).

The player that visits all the flowers first wins.

Name: Confrontation: Dogs of War
Description:
From Rackham's Website:

Take a company’s fate into your hands!

This first extension for Confrontation 3 proposes a new gaming mode that introduces a new way of playing your favorite skirmish game. Indeed, it provides a method of creating a free company made up of fighters from the four corners of Aarklash to amass glory and riches. The rules on alliances must nevertheless be respected.

This new gaming mode is based on the idea that the battles they wage have consequences on the soldiers and that these consequences cause an evolution of those they affect. Unlike the old Incarnation system, which was focused on a Character, it gives you the opportunity to unite different fighters, to personalize them and to let them evolve freely from one exciting skirmish scenario to the next. This new gaming mode makes the fun of a good game of Confrontation last well beyond each battle by involving recruiting, improving characteristics, abilities and equipment, managing the wounded and the fighters’ resources, etc.

The young free companies will need new challenges. That’s why this first extension provides enhanced rules on fortifications and scenery, as well as the revision of those on nexuses (see Cry Havoc, vol. 01).

And this extension has many other surprises in store…

Expands:

    Confrontation

Name: Het grote Pluk van de Petteflet spel
Description:
"Het grote Pluk van de Petteflet spel" is a Dutch children's game. It derives its theme from the well-known (for Dutch and Flemish at least) children's book "Pluk van de Petteflet", also known as "Towtruck Pluck" in English, by Dutch children's book writer Annie M.G. Schmidt. The players relive Pluk's adventures during the game.

In essence it is a roll and move game: each in turn rolls a die and advances his pawn on the track. The winner is the first one to reach the finish. But to be allowed to finish, you must have the game token (Pluk's pigeon friend Dollie). That token is acquired by landing on spaces marked with a pigeon, or by landing next to the owner of the token.
A few spaces on the board allow you to take another player's pawn and put it next to yours.

The board is lavishly illustrated with scenes from the book.

Name: Who Ate All the Pies?!
Description:
From the Publisher:

"It’s the big game.  You’re there.  You’re in your seat.  You’re ready.  But then, Oh-oh!  Suddenly you feel the need – the need for greed!

That’s right, it’s PIE TIME!!  Quick, out of your seat!  Out of the stadium!! Go get those pies and get back with them before the clock runs out!!!

But, hold on! You’re not alone.  Look around you!  There are other players – and they’re after YOUR PIES!!  They’re just as needy, just as greedy, but are they just as speedy as you?!"

And from a publisher's press release:
"The setting of the game is a sports stadium surrounded by concession stands selling Pies.  Your playing piece is one of 8 comically greedy cartoon characters with a single-minded desire for Pies.  With the clock ticking, the object of the game is to move your character out of the stadium, rush from Pie-stand to Pie-stand collecting as many Pies as possible and return with them to your seat before the time runs out.  But, along the way, there are a myriad of dirty tricks and hazards.  Elbow your opponents as you pass and make them drop their Pies!  Trip them up and make them miss a turn!  Make them slip on Banana Peels and make them drop a Pie AND miss a turn!!  Lock them out of turnstiles!  Lock them out of bathrooms!  And, of course, your opponents are going to try to do the same to you.  Plus, you’ve got to be careful of those turnstiles – you and your Pies might not fit through them!  And, all the time, you’ve got to watch out for those Pies – some of them are Dodgy Pies!  They might not like you as much as you like them!!"

In this game the players' decide how many rounds they will play and set the timer for the game.

Name: Pendoka
Description:
Pendoka is a set of small wooden spheres and plastic connectors. The spheres have four holes each, so you can build dodecahedrons and different three-dimensional structures with penta- and hexagons, varying the possible forms, twisted and shrinked ... the fact you can turn the connectors even if it is already sticking in a hole, offers many ways for construction.

There are different kinds of games you can play with Pendoka, from easy to difficult:
At "Master of Pentagon" the players get a certain number of colored spheres and connectors, each player his own color. The goal is to build after a couple of rules and hinder the others from building. Winner is the first player who built all his parts.

At "Fünferkette" (five-in-a-row) the winner is, who built the first five of his parts in a row, at "Your Turn" you have to enclose a sphere of the contrary player ...

There are even more Games in it, so Pendoka is not a single game of its own, but more a system, like Spiel (with hundreds of dice) - you can create your own rules, build as you want or have a look on the website for new ideas.

Home Page: http://www.pendoka.de

Name: The King's Highway
Description:
Components:

One Box with game rules printed on the top lid
One rectangular board
16 wooden disks (four for each player)
three spinners

Idea of the game:

Each player must get their four travelers (wooden disks) from the starting square along a path of spiraling squares to the "Inn" (the finishing square.)  Players alternate turns spinning a spinner and moving one of their travelers the indicated number of spaces.  Players cannot move a traveler to a space that is already occupied.  Along the path is a "highwayman" space that requires the traveler to stop until the "highwayman" is paid (payment is made by spinning the correct color.) First player to get all four of their travelers to the Inn wins.

Name: Rolaire
Description:
Rolaire is a played with colored balls, 5 red, 4 yellow, and 3 blue.  You 'back' your fancy as to which colored combination will end up at the bottom of the customized ramp. There are ten winning combinations with the odds of favorite at 5/2 to the outsider at 72/1 !

The Rolaire box itself is made of plastic with a wooden surround.  It tilts in the middle to create a gentle slope that the balls roll down.  The surface of the board is made up of several channels and sloping hazards scientifically designed to impede and divert the balls on their way down to the winning slot at the bottom of the board.

A roulette type of mat is in play to place your hunches and there are several modes of play.  A very rare game indeed!

Name: Pig Tickler
Description: Pig Tickler is a game for any number of enthusiastic players, the more the merrier. Lancers on unicycles ride around a field attempting to score points or gold rumps by stabbing a mechanical pig, whilst avoiding being knocked over and trampled by the pig.

Name: Mozog
Description:
A Nine Men's Morris Variant

Alignment type game with alignment inhibiting means , United States Patent 4579347

Abstract: A game board apparatus (10) comprising a plurality of playing pieces (12), and a game board (11); wherein the game board has a number x of diminishing diameter geometrical configurations (14) in the form of squares (15) formed from and attached to one another by solid (17) and broken (16) lines that delineate the movement of the playing pieces (12) on the game board (11).

Name: Who Framed Roger Rabbit: Dip Flip
Description: Play as Judge Doom tossing the toons in the dip or Eddie Valiant trying to save their very celluloid skins.

Name: Zizzlingers Power Game
Description:
Zizzlingers Miniature Collectible Game Pieces - with Power Game.

Zizzlingers are plastic figures that are revealed like those little sponges that expand in water. Part of the fun is putting your pack in the water and seeing who comes out.

Zizzlingers figures each have a symbol on the bottom that is one of five symbols in a kind of extended Rock-Paper-Scissors (each symbol defeats two others, ties its own symbol, and cannot defeat two others). Each figure only has one symbol that is used each time it is used in play.

Zizzlingers come in different licensed properties, some of which are Marvel Heroes, Disney Princesses, and Disney/Pixar characters. Zizzlingers gives you two to three figures in one package for about $5.

Home Page: http://www.zizzle.com/zizzlingers.html

Name: Ring My Nose
Description:
Ages 4 and up can enjoy this great little party game. Try to get all three rings on my nose!

Comes with 1 game board and 3 rings for tossing.

Name: Whirl Out
Description:
In Whirl Out, luck and skill both come into play as players try to keep their marbles on the whirling wheel.

During the game, players spin to determine into which section of the 3-D wheel they must place one of their colored marbles. After the marble is placed into one of the marble holders on the wheel, the wheel will turn under the weight of the marble and will eventually come to a stop. The next player proceeds in the same way.

When the wheel rotates, some marbles may fall through the back of the wheel and down a marble return chute and into the return well, where the marbles are picked up by their respective players to be placed again, in turn.

If a player spins "Wipe Out" on the spinner, they place the steel ball in one of the empty marble holders. The weight of the steel ball can whirl the wheel back and forth several times before it comes to rest.

Players continue, in turn, to place their marbles on the wheel. When one player successfully places all of their marbles--and the wheel is at rest--that player wins the game.

Name: Bolsa de Valores
Description: This is not the same game relesead by Grow (later renamed Ações Exame). This one was released by Estrela before 1971 and is much more simple. Players buy and sell stock and try to make more money, from negotiation and from profits.

Name: Portcullis
Description:
Portcullis features an upright wooden board shaped like a castle gate, which is very thick to prevent players from seeing each other’s pieces before placed.  It has a 6x6 grid of holes into which 36 playing blocks—18 dark, 18 light—can be pushed.  There are two wooden trays for each player to sort their wooden playing blocks.  (When not in use, the pieces, trays, and board are all able to stack on top of each other for display.)  The blocks have one of four different flags painted on either end, always a different flag on each side for a total of six combinations of flags.

To win the game, a player must create a pattern of flags on his side, the shape of which is to be agreed upon before the game.  It can be a square shape (A) or a flag shape (B):

AA
AA

B
--BB
B

or

---B
BB
---B

Typically the flag shape is used, as it is harder to block.  A player’s pattern may utilize flags from either player’s pieces (the directions the flags point is of no consequence) and the pattern is not affected by any other flags in the board.

Players take turns choosing their blocks in secret and placing them according to a key painted on the upper right hand corner of each side of the board, pointing the flag on the player’s side according to the key in order to remember what flag is on the opposite side.  When either player sees a complete pattern on their own side, they turn the board and the game ends.  A draw can occur if all blocks are played with no pattern completed.  The rules provide for several variations that include bluffing, different goals, pushing blocks out, and different endings.

Name: Sharks and Jets
Description:
Two street gangs both alike in dignity, 
In West Manhattan, where we lay our scene, 
Do battle for their turf with pirouettes,
Leaping, spinning, fighting the Sharks and Jets.

This is a tactical combat game based on the musical West Side Story. Players control rival street gangs, The Sharks and The Jets, that are represented by individual counters. Gang members attack by snapping their fingers, singing and performing dance moves. They attempt to break the other gang's cool. Each character has a cool and uncool side. Leaders can rally uncool gang members. All combat is resolved on the Choreography Results Table.

Name: Pro Table Games Co.: Hockey
Description:
A stat driven hockey game based on season performance.  Individual player cards, face-off and puck handling charts all combine to simulate the fastest game on earth.

"Breathtaking realism and exciting statistical accuracy" - box top quote

Name: Alchymia: La Quête du Cristal Noir
Description:
From BGN:

Alchymia - La Quête du Cristal Noir (The Quest for the Black Crystal) is a small print (500) game, self-published by Swiss designer Frank Schwab. The game accommodates 2-5 players and plays in roughly 30-60 min (my best guess). Images and rules (in French) are available at the Alchymia website.

Each player is given a personal board and 3 potion cards and 8 atomic element tokens in 5 colors are placed in the central reserve. Each potion card depicts 1-4 atomic elements used to create the 5 Elemental Crystals (Fire, Water, Earth, Air and Time). Players attempt to collect and place the atomic element tokens on their board in such a way as to mimic the current configuration of one of the 5 crystals. They do this, in turn, by playing a potion card to retrieve an atomic element token of one of the types shown on the card from the central reserve and place it on their game board. They can also choose to remove an element token from their game board by playing a potion card with that element type. Alternatively, players can pass their turn by wiping their board clean of tokens.

Once a player has matched a crystal configuration, they wipe their board of tokens, collect the crystal structure card they matched, reveal a new crystal configuration card and begin collecting beads for another type of crystal. The twist is that each type of crystal confers upon its owner an additional special power (for example, the Time Crystal allows you to rearrange your board during your turn, instead of taking or removing an element token). The first person to collect each of the 5 crystals becomes the master alchemist who can create the coveted Black Crystal.

Name: Fooly
Description:
From BGN:

Ergomia is a small French publisher of games that uses ergonomic comma-shaped cards. Their newest game, designed by Marcel Rigaut, is a kid’s symbol matching game revolving around the animal food chain. Each card depicts an animal and the 1-3 things it likes to eat. Players can start a new food chain circle by playing a green card or they can add to an existing food chain circle by playing an orange or blue card with at least 1 matching food element to the adjacent card(s). The shape of the cards allows 8 cards to be played in a circle or “rose”. Whoever places the 8th card in a food chain circle gets to claim the set. Whoever claims the most sets is the winner.
